text:
Q: Facebook Graph API Returning Empty Data Set A:

I added pages_show_list and business_management permissions to the user token and successfully fetched the pages using Facebook Graph API v24.0.

Q: any opinion on use AI for vibe coding as a newbie A:

valid point man, i've been thinking like that now a days

Q: EF Core: How to dynamically use an entity by table name (string) for data synchronization? A:

You're looking at this backwards. In fact, this sounds like an XY Problem - you have a problem X (mapping to different schemas? Tenants?) and assume you need to change "table resolution". When that doesn't work (it doesn't exist), you ask for that, not the original problem. And synchronization/replication has nothing to do with objects in the first place, so using an ORM is the wrong tool for the job.

EF and all full-featured ORMs deals with entities not tables. It doesn't resolve tables. A DbContex is a Unit-of-Work, not a database connection. It's meant to load an entire graph of related objects at a time and persist changes made to all of them at once, as if you were working with an object database.

Mappings are already done at runtime when configuring the entity model, whether you use the Fluent API and ToTable or ToView in OnModelCreating, a configuration type, or the data annotations or conventions to generate the same calls and model as the fluent API.

BUT that means it's completely inappropriate for synchronization and replication jobs. There are no entities, and the real concepts are table, column, transformation , incremental load, full refresh , primary key, update key etc. If you check eg SlingData's replication example for SQL Server you won't see any ORM concepts - just connection strings, table names, keys and a mode, if you want incremental update.

sling run \
  --src-conn src_sqlserver \
  --src-stream "sales.orders" \
  --src-query "SELECT * FROM sales.orders WHERE order_date >= '2023-01-01'" \
  --tgt-conn tgt_sqlserver \
  --tgt-object "sales.orders_2023" \
  --mode incremental \
  --primary-key order_id \
  --update-key order_date \
  --table-keys "{ unique: [order_number] }" # sets unique index

ADO.NET is the actual API that connects to databases and provides abstractions like DbComman, DbDataReader etc. You can use that to execute a query, load data from one database and insert it into another. Specific database drivers have ways to bulk load data eg the SqlBulkCopy class of Microsoft.Data.SqlClient accepts a DbDataReader as input that can come from any database. NpgSql has similar features.

Another option is to extract the source data into text file and use the target's bulk insert tools to import that data.

The table columns can be detected by querying the INFORMATION_SCHEMA.COLUMNS table that's found in all database products, to find a table's columns and types. This can even be used to create tables, or detect changes between the source and target tables or queries.

Tools like SlingData will replicate new data incrementally by retrieving the target's maximum update key value (eg ID or updated_at ) column, and retrieve source data that's above that. Another option is to retrieve eg the last 1 week of data and insert new rows while updating older ones.
